metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Ministerial Services Association

facts.text: Consequent on the war, there was a phenomenal rise in the price of foodstuffs and of other essential commodities, and among the persons worst hit by it were the Government servants.
Central and Provincial Governments sanctioned a grant of grain allowances to Government servants under various Resolutions passed in 1940.

Central Government scheme: its employees stationed in various Provinces received the same benefit as the respective Provincial Government employees, but this was found unsuitable as allowances by Provincial Governments were not uniform.
Central Government appointed Central Pay Commission on 10th May, 1946, to enquire into conditions of service, pay scales, etc.
Central Pay Commission, presided by Sir S. Varadachariar, recommended dearness allowance on a specified scale in report dated 3rd May, 1947.
Government of Central Provinces and Berar appointed Pay Committee on 27th May, 1947, to examine Central Pay Commission recommendations.
Pay Committee recommended dearness allowance on a scale identical to Commission for salaries above Rs. 400 per mensem, but less for Rs. 400 or less, in report dated 22nd June, 1948.
Government accepted Pay Committee recommendations by Resolution dated 16th September, 1948.
Difference in scales caused dissatisfaction among employees; unsuccessful attempts for redress; filed petition under Article 226 through representative (respondent).
In petition: Alleged discrimination in adopting GOI rates for >Rs.400 but not for <=Rs.400; right to equal treatment with Central Govt servants.
High Court (Sinha C.J. and Bhutt J.) held claim justiciable, differentiation unreasonable, Resolution bad under Art 14; directed State to reconsider.
Appeal to Supreme Court by State on certificate under Art 132(1).
Pay Committee based scale on current prices, not cost of living index; considered revised basic pay and State financial resources.
State passed Resolutions on 4th January 1951 and 6th October 1951 adopting Commission scale for certain other categories.

legal_issues.text: Whether grant of dearness allowance is justiciable, such that mandamus or direction can issue.
Whether Resolution dated 16th September 1948 fixing scale of dearness allowance is repugnant to Article 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: State Government should uniformly adopt GOI rates; discrimination in two-fold slab (GOI rates >Rs.400, lower <=Rs.400); right to equal treatment with Central Govt servants.
Once Resolution passed under Rule 44 FR, it is 'law' under Art 13(3)(a); if infringes Art 14, void.

respondent_arguments.text: Grant of dearness allowance ex gratia, not justiciable; no right, no mandamus.
Resolution not discriminatory; scheme graded by pay slabs, uniform within slabs (except slight city adjustment); no violation of Art 14.
Committee did not adopt Commission report in part; independent approach based on different principles (current prices, basic pay revision, State finances).

court_reasoning.text: Under Rule 44 FR, dearness allowance discretionary; no right in servants, no duty on State; not justiciable; no mandamus or direction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dearness allowance matter of grace, not right; distinguished from arrears of salary cases.

court_reasoning.text: Resolution scheme: graded by pay slabs with progressive reduction; uniform within slabs; no discrimination within Resolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in scheme obnoxious to Art 14.

court_reasoning.text: Art 14 does not permit striking down State law by comparing with Central law; different legislatures/authorities; must examine impugned law alone.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Union and States distinct; no comparative study.

court_reasoning.text: Committee approached independently: current prices basis, excluded pay element due to basic pay revision, considered State finances; coincidence where same as Commission.

holdings.text: Claim for dearness allowance not justiciable; no writ/direction issues.
Resolution dated 16th September 1948 not repugnant to Article 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab Province v. Pandit Tara Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Arrears of salary justiciable as debt; not applicable to prospective grant of allowance.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved Tara Chand; salary not bounty, recoverable by action.
Petition of right lies only for matters of right, not grace.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art 14 equality; Art 13 law void if violates Part III; distinct Union/State; writ jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Discretionary power to grant compensatory allowances like dearness allowance.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment and direction to reconsider dearness allowance; held claim not justiciable and Resolution not violative of Art 14.

key_quotes.text: "Under this provision, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on non-justiciability under Rule 44 FR.

key_quotes.text: "Article 14 does not authorise the striking down of a law of one State on the ground that in contrast with a law of another State on the same subject its provisions are discriminatory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on no comparative invalidity between Centre and State.

key_quotes.text: "It is erroneous to suppose that a petition of right will lie for matters which are of grace and not of right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
